config.question: Why wasn’t the states’ decision to award voting rights for all white males considered radical or controversial in 1820?

choices.content: Since so many owned land, the change followed well-established principles.
The decision was the result of an amendment made to the Constitution.
The change was a consequence of Congress’s decision to abolish slavery.
This change was slowly implemented over a period of sixty years from 1817 onward.

answer_3.response: By the 1820s, most states had removed the last barriers to voting for all white males. This change was not as radical or controversial as it would be later in nineteenth-century Europe; so many Americans owned land that most voters were still men of property.
